entry.title: Building a GL Account Hierarchy for SAC Planning with CDS Views - Part 2 ( Building the Hierarchy )
entry.content:
Table of Contents:

  • Overview on this Blog
  • Approach
  • Technical Details and Source code
  • Leaf and header node Handling in SAC
  • Query 2: Hierarchy for Leaf Level
  • Query 3: Hierarchy for Header Level
  • Conclusion

Overview on this Blog

Hi SAP Community,
This is part two of a three part blog series on How to Build a GL Account Hierarchy for SAC Planning with CDS Views.

  • Part1 - Loading the ID & DESC of the GL
  • Part2 - Loading the hierarchy
  • Part3 - Loading the Desc for the Hierarchy nodes 

In Part 1, we focused on loading the GL Account ID and Description into an SAC public dimension by selectively filtering GLs from the Financial Statement Version (FSV). This ensured that only the GL accounts relevant for our planning process were loaded, avoiding unnecessary noise in SAC input forms. If you haven't read part1, I recommend you reading that first before this blog.

In this part, we will extend the same approach and focus on loading the GL hierarchy structure required for SAC Planning. This includes both leaf-level GL accounts and the header nodes that form the hierarchy.

 

Approach

Although SAP provides standard CDS hierarchy views(C_GLAccountHierarchyNode) , it is not feasible to consume a portion of the FSV with the available CDS View.

Instead of loading the entire GL hierarchy, we restrict ourselves to specific FSV branches relevant to the planning module (Sales, OPEX, CAPEX, etc.). The important assumption here is that the master nodes of the FSV do not change and the FSV is limited to a maximum of 8 Level of drill down , making them reliable anchors for hierarchy extraction.

The hierarchy is constructed by:

  1. Identifying the leaf-level GL accounts
  2. Traversing upwards level by level until the root node
  3. Capturing all intermediate hierarchy nodes in the process

This traversal is implemented using multiple CDS views, Since CDS does not support recursion we would be iteratively joining and passing the parent of lower levels as the Children of next level until we reach the root. At the final step, all hierarchy levels are unioned into a single CDS view, which is then exposed via OData and consumed in the SAC public dimension. 

Don't worry if it feels confusing at first, it will start to make lot more sense once we see the CDS architecture and Source code.

Technical Details and Source code

ZCDS_GLHIER_BACKBONE

This is the Base hierarchy view that combines HRRP_NODE with the standard CDS view (C_GLAccountHierarchyNode) to fetch the required FSV nodes and underlying hierarchy nodes. The reason we have joined HRRP_NODE is to obtain the node details. This CDS view will be propagated to the top level and be used as a foundation by higher CDS views.

@AbapCatalog.sqlViewName: 'ZSQL_HIER'
@AbapCatalog.compiler.compareFilter: true
@AbapCatalog.preserveKey: true
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #CHECK
@EndUserText.label: 'GL hierarchy Foundation'
@Analytics.dataExtraction.enabled: true
@OData.publish: true
define view ZCDS_GLHIER_BACKBONE as 


select distinct from hrrp_node as a
inner join C_GLAccountHierarchyNode as b
    on a.hryid = b.GLAccountHierarchy and a.nodevalue = b.GLAccount
  {
    key a.hryid,
    key a.hrynode,
    key a.parnode,
    key a.nodevalue,
    a.nodetype,
    b.GLAccount,
    b.HierarchyNode,
    b.ParentNode,
    b.NodeType as STD_nodetype
}
where (

(a.hryid='FSV1') and. -- Replace with your relevant FSV for SAC Planning
(a.nodetype='L' or a.nodetype='D') and  --Fetches line items containing Leaf or Directory nodes.

-- Filters only the relevant Nodes needed for Planning. 
-- ParNode value may differ based on your FSV.
((a.parnode='08' or a.parnode='09'or a.parnode='017' or a.parnode='011')                   //Sales         (08->Turnover, 09->COS, 017-> Taxation, 011->Other income)
or (a.parnode='013' or a.parnode='014' or a.parnode='016')              //OPEX          (013->Selling & distribution cost, 014->General & Admin cost, 016-> Finance cost)
or (a.parnode='012')                                                    //Workforce     (012->Indirect payroll cost)
or (a.parnode='00ASSETS' or a.parnode='00LIABILITS' or a.parnode='028')                //CAPEX         (00ASSETS->ASSETS, 00LIABILITS->LIABILITIES & EQUITY, 028->Depreciation)
or (a.parnode='0117'))                                                  //Inventory     (0117-> Inventory)
)

ZCDS_GLHIER_GL_BASE:

This CDS View provides a clean GL-only child–parent mapping within the hierarchy, used as a reusable base for hierarchy traversal.

@AbapCatalog.sqlViewName: 'ZSQL_GLBASE'
@AbapCatalog.compiler.compareFilter: true
@AbapCatalog.preserveKey: true
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #CHECK
@EndUserText.label: 'For getting Plannable GLs'
define view ZCDS_GLHIER_GL_BASE as select distinct from C_GLAccountHierarchyNode as a

    {
    a.GLAccountHierarchy,
    a.GLAccount,
    a.HierarchyNode as Child,
    a.ParentNode as Parent,
    a.SACAccountType,
    a.NodeType as STD_nodetype
}
where (

(a.GLAccountHierarchy='FSV1') --Replace with your FSV
and (a.NodeType='N' or a.NodeType='R') 

)

ZCDS_GLHIER_LVL8_LEAF:

Using ZCDS_GLHIER_BACKBONE we will extract all the Leaf GLs and its immediate parent. Also while keeping track of the MasterParent.

@AbapCatalog.sqlViewName: 'ZSQL_LVL8'
@AbapCatalog.compiler.compareFilter: true
@AbapCatalog.preserveKey: true
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #CHECK
@EndUserText.label: 'Leaf level 8 - Most granular'
define view ZCDS_GLHIER_LVL8_LEAF as select distinct from 
ZCDS_GLHIER_BACKBONE as a {
    a.parnode as MasterParent,
    a.nodevalue as Child,
    a.ParentNode as Parent
}

ZCDS_GLHIER_LVL7_PARENT:

@AbapCatalog.sqlViewName: 'ZSQL_LVL7'
@AbapCatalog.compiler.compareFilter: true
@AbapCatalog.preserveKey: true
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #CHECK
@EndUserText.label: 'Parent Level7 - One step above leaf'
define view ZCDS_GLHIER_LVL7_PARENT as select distinct from 

ZCDS_GLHIER_BACKBONE as a 
{
    a.hryid,
    a.nodetype,
    a.parnode as MasterParent,
    a.ParentNode
}
The Code below this portion is simple and easy to follow along, The concept is simple.
Pass the parent of one level to the child of the higher level, that will give the parent child relationship all the way till the root level is reached.
 
ZCDS_GLHIER_LVL6_PARENT:
@AbapCatalog.sqlViewName: 'ZSQL_LVL6'
@AbapCatalog.compiler.compareFilter: true
@AbapCatalog.preserveKey: true
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #CHECK
@EndUserText.label: 'Parent Level6 - Two step above leaf'
define view ZCDS_GLHIER_LVL6_PARENT as select distinct from 
ZCDS_GLHIER_GL_BASE as a inner join ZCDS_GLHIER_LVL7_PARENT as b on a.Child = b.ParentNode
{
    a.GLAccountHierarchy,
    b.MasterParent,
    a.Child,
    a.Parent
}

ZCDS_GLHIER_LVL5_PARENT:

@AbapCatalog.sqlViewName: 'ZSQL_LVL5'
@AbapCatalog.compiler.compareFilter: true
@AbapCatalog.preserveKey: true
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #CHECK
@EndUserText.label: 'Parent Level5 - Three step above leaf'
define view ZCDS_GLHIER_LVL5_PARENT as select distinct from 
ZCDS_GLHIER_GL_BASE as a inner join ZCDS_GLHIER_LVL6_PARENT as b on a.Child = b.Parent
{
    a.GLAccountHierarchy,
    b.MasterParent,
    a.Child,
    a.Parent
}

ZCDS_GLHIER_LVL4_PARENT:

@AbapCatalog.sqlViewName: 'ZSQL_LVL4'
@AbapCatalog.compiler.compareFilter: true
@AbapCatalog.preserveKey: true
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #CHECK
@EndUserText.label: 'Parent Level4 - Four step above leaf'
define view ZCDS_GLHIER_LVL4_PARENT as select distinct from 
ZCDS_GLHIER_GL_BASE as a inner join ZCDS_GLHIER_LVL5_PARENT as b on a.Child = b.Parent
{
    a.GLAccountHierarchy,
    b.MasterParent,
    a.Child,
    a.Parent
}
ZCDS_GLHIER_LVL3_PARENT:
@AbapCatalog.sqlViewName: 'ZSQL_LVL3'
@AbapCatalog.compiler.compareFilter: true
@AbapCatalog.preserveKey: true
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #CHECK
@EndUserText.label: 'Parent Level3 - Five step above leaf'
define view ZCDS_GLHIER_LVL3_PARENT as select distinct from 
ZCDS_GLHIER_GL_BASE as a inner join ZCDS_GLHIER_LVL4_PARENT as b on a.Child = b.Parent
{
    a.GLAccountHierarchy,
    b.MasterParent,
    a.Child,
    a.Parent
}

ZCDS_GLHIER_LVL2_PARENT:

@AbapCatalog.sqlViewName: 'ZSQL_LVL2'
@AbapCatalog.compiler.compareFilter: true
@AbapCatalog.preserveKey: true
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #CHECK
@EndUserText.label: 'Parent Level2 - Six step above leaf'
define view ZCDS_GLHIER_LVL2_PARENT as select distinct from 
ZCDS_GLHIER_GL_BASE as a inner join ZCDS_GLHIER_LVL3_PARENT as b on a.Child = b.Parent
{
    a.GLAccountHierarchy,
    b.MasterParent,
    a.Child,
    a.Parent
}

ZCDS_GLHIER_LVL1_PARENT:

@AbapCatalog.sqlViewName: 'ZSQL_LVL1'
@AbapCatalog.compiler.compareFilter: true
@AbapCatalog.preserveKey: true
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #CHECK
@EndUserText.label: 'Parent Level1 - 7 step above leaf'
define view ZCDS_GLHIER_LVL1_PARENT as select distinct from 
ZCDS_GLHIER_GL_BASE as a inner join ZCDS_GLHIER_LVL2_PARENT as b on a.Child = b.Parent
{
    a.GLAccountHierarchy,
    b.MasterParent,
    a.Child,
    a.Parent
}
ZCDS_GLHIER_LVL0_ROOT:
After iterating the same procedure 8 times, we would have traversed 8 levels above the leaf which is also apparently the root node.
We have established 8 levels of iterations to achieve the maximum depth of 8levels of drill down, i.e, the maximum level of drill down possible in the S4/HANA FINANCE module for the creation of FSV.
@AbapCatalog.sqlViewName: 'ZSQL_LVL0'
@AbapCatalog.compiler.compareFilter: true
@AbapCatalog.preserveKey: true
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #CHECK
@EndUserText.label: 'Root Level - 8 step above leaf'
define view ZCDS_GLHIER_LVL0_ROOT as select distinct from 
ZCDS_GLHIER_GL_BASE as a inner join ZCDS_GLHIER_LVL1_PARENT as b on a.Child = b.Parent
{
    a.GLAccountHierarchy,
    b.MasterParent,
    a.Child,
    a.Parent
}
ZCDS_GLHIER_FLAT_SAC:
At the final layer we would be unioning all the underlying levels ( Lvl0- root, lvl 1 to Lvl6 - Intermediate nodes, Lvl8 - Leaf).
The important thing here is to retain the MasterParent, which lets us identify which part of master branch the intermediate nodes and leaves are from.
 
If the source system has maintained the SACAccountType then well and good, if not you can maintain the SACAccountType like I did. (INC- income, EXP - expense, AST - Asset, LEQ - Liabilities, NFIN - NonFinancial). These will play crucial role in the aggregation, as GLs with AccountType EXP, LEQ will be subtracted rather than getting added. This will help SAC understand the signage and what to do next.
@AbapCatalog.sqlViewName: 'ZSQL_TOP'
@AbapCatalog.compiler.compareFilter: true
@AbapCatalog.preserveKey: true
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #CHECK
@EndUserText.label: 'Union of all levels 1 to 8'
@Analytics.dataExtraction.enabled: true
@OData.publish: true
define view ZCDS_GLHIER_FLAT_SAC as select distinct from ZCDS_GLHIER_LVL8_LEAF as a 
{
    key a.MasterParent,
    key a.Parent,
    key a.Child,
    //a.SACAccountType,
    case when a.Parent='' then '' else(case when (a.MasterParent='08' or a.MasterParent='011') then 'INC' else (case when (a.MasterParent='00ASSETS' or a.MasterParent='0117') then 'AST' else (case when a.MasterParent='00LIABILITS' then 'LEQ' else 'EXP' end) end) end) end as SACAccountType,
    'Children' as Nodetype
}
union 

select distinct from ZCDS_GLHIER_LVL6_PARENT as a {
    key a.MasterParent,
    key a.Parent,
    key a.Child,
    //a.SACAccountType,
    case when a.Parent='' then '' else(case when (a.MasterParent='08' or a.MasterParent='011') then 'INC' else (case when (a.MasterParent='00ASSETS' or a.MasterParent='0117') then 'AST' else (case when a.MasterParent='00LIABILITS' then 'LEQ' else 'EXP' end) end) end) end as SACAccountType,
    'Node' as Nodetype
}
union 

select distinct from ZCDS_GLHIER_LVL5_PARENT as a {
    key a.MasterParent,
    key a.Parent,
    key a.Child,
    //a.SACAccountType,
    case when a.Parent='' then '' else(case when (a.MasterParent='08' or a.MasterParent='011') then 'INC' else (case when (a.MasterParent='00ASSETS' or a.MasterParent='0117') then 'AST' else (case when a.MasterParent='00LIABILITS' then 'LEQ' else 'EXP' end) end) end) end as SACAccountType,
    'Node' as Nodetype
}

union 

select distinct from ZCDS_GLHIER_LVL4_PARENT as a {
    key a.MasterParent,
    key a.Parent,
    key a.Child,
    //a.SACAccountType,
    case when a.Parent='' then '' else(case when (a.MasterParent='08' or a.MasterParent='011') then 'INC' else (case when (a.MasterParent='00ASSETS' or a.MasterParent='0117') then 'AST' else (case when a.MasterParent='00LIABILITS' then 'LEQ' else 'EXP' end) end) end) end as SACAccountType,
    'Node' as Nodetype
}
union 

select distinct from ZCDS_GLHIER_LVL3_PARENT as a {
    key a.MasterParent,
    key a.Parent,
    key a.Child,
    //a.SACAccountType,
    case when a.Parent='' then '' else(case when (a.MasterParent='08' or a.MasterParent='011') then 'INC' else (case when (a.MasterParent='00ASSETS' or a.MasterParent='0117') then 'AST' else (case when a.MasterParent='00LIABILITS' then 'LEQ' else 'EXP' end) end) end) end as SACAccountType,
    'Node' as Nodetype
}
union 

select from ZCDS_GLHIER_LVL2_PARENT as a {
    key a.MasterParent,
    key a.Parent,
    key a.Child,
    //a.SACAccountType,
    case when a.Parent='' then '' else(case when (a.MasterParent='08' or a.MasterParent='011') then 'INC' else (case when (a.MasterParent='00ASSETS' or a.MasterParent='0117') then 'AST' else (case when a.MasterParent='00LIABILITS' then 'LEQ' else 'EXP' end) end) end) end as SACAccountType,
    'Node' as Nodetype
}
union 

select distinct from ZCDS_GLHIER_LVL1_PARENT as a {
    key a.MasterParent,
    key a.Parent,
    key a.Child,
    //a.SACAccountType,
    case when a.Parent='' then '' else(case when (a.MasterParent='08' or a.MasterParent='011') then 'INC' else (case when (a.MasterParent='00ASSETS' or a.MasterParent='0117') then 'AST' else (case when a.MasterParent='00LIABILITS' then 'LEQ' else 'EXP' end) end) end) end as SACAccountType,
    'Node' as Nodetype
}
union 

select distinct from ZCDS_GLHIER_LVL0_ROOT as a {
    key a.MasterParent,
    key a.Parent,
    key a.Child,
    //a.SACAccountType,
    case when a.Parent='' then '' else(case when (a.MasterParent='08' or a.MasterParent='011') then 'INC' else (case when (a.MasterParent='00ASSETS' or a.MasterParent='0117') then 'AST' else (case when a.MasterParent='00LIABILITS' then 'LEQ' else 'EXP' end) end) end) end as SACAccountType,
    'Node' as Nodetype
}

Leaf and header node Handling in SAC

The hierarchy loading is split into two logical parts:

  • Nodetype - Children (Leaf nodes): All Leaf GLs and it's immediate parent
  • Nodetype - Node (Header nodes): All intermediate Nodes and their respective parents upto root.

We would be Loading the hierarchy in two steps in SAC as per the concept above. We will be using our ZCDS_GLHIER_FLAT_SAC cds view.

Query 2: Hierarchy for Leaf Level

Remember the MasterParent field we kept Intact? With the help of that we can choose whichever MasterNode we want to load into our public dimension. If you are loading the Hierarchy for the SALES GL Account dimension, just simply select the MasterNodes that point to Sales. In our Part1 blog, we loaded the GLs of nodes Turnover(08), CostofSales(09), OtherIncome(11) and Taxation(17), So we'll do the same over here. 


In this query2, we will be loading only the leaf and its immediate hierarchy first. Hence we have selected Nodetype as 'Children'. The below image will give you a clear picture on what is happening.

Since queries in public dimensions work on update method, the hierarchy & Account type property will get updated based on the above mapped information.

The sample result would be like this. 

ID

Description

Hierarchy

Account type

40010000

Revenue - Good (Export)

FSV1_019

INC

40010001

Revenue - Good (Service)

FSV1_019

INC

Query 3: Hierarchy for Header Level

Now that the Hierarchy for the leaf level is done, the remaining thing to concentrate now is to populate the nodes and its respective hierarchy details. The only difference being we just need to create another query with the same dimensions, but the important thing is to change the filter for Nodetype as 'Node'.

This will fetch only the details from our intermediate levels. From Lvl6 to Root level.

In this query3, we will be loading only the nodes and its hierarchy, this continues all the way till the root. Hence we have selected Nodetype as 'Node'. The below image will give you a complete picture on what is happening.

The sample result would be like this. 

ID

Description

Hierarchy

Account type

40010000

Revenue - Good (Export)

FSV1_019

INC

40010001

Revenue - Good (Service)

FSV1_019

INC

FSV1_011

 

FSV1_0FSV1

INC

FSV1_017

 

FSV1_0FSV1

INC

FSV1_018

 

FSV1_08

INC

FSV1_019

 

FSV1_08

INC

FSV1_020

 

FSV1_08

INC

FSV1_0FSV1

 

FSV1_

 

FSV1_

 

<root>

 

FSV1_08

 

FSV1_0FSV1

INC

FSV1_09

 

FSV1_0FSV1

INC

 

Conclusion

In this blog, we covered how to build a GL hierarchy for SAC Planning by selectively extracting FSV branches and traversing the hierarchy using multiple CDS views. This layered approach ensures a clean and future proof hierarchy in SAC. In the next part, we will focus on loading descriptions for hierarchy header nodes to complete the setup.

I hope this blog was helpful. This was my first time explaining something in detail. If you liked this level of explanation, do let me know. I’ll consider this feedback while writing my upcoming blogs. ✌️

entry.title: Automatic creation of Warehouse Product Master in SAP EWM.
entry.content:
In S/4HANA embedded EWM, when a material (product) is created/extended from the ERP side (MM), EWM can auto‑create the corresponding Warehouse Product master (/SCWM/MAT1) for the relevant warehouse(s). This removes manual maintenance in EWM and keeps the product master aligned across ERP and EWM. The trigger and routing logic are delivered via BTE (Business Transaction Event) and standard integration checks.

Required Configuration :

  1. Open Transaction code FIDF
  2. Choose "Settings->Products->...of a customer". Create a new entry

  1. Choose "Settings->P/S Modules->...of a customer". Create a new entry for event 00001250, product(created in step 2) and  sample function module /SCWM/SAMPLE_MATLWH_00001250

By using the BTE event 00001250 and sample function module  /SCWM/SAMPLE_MATLWH_00001250 available in SAP Standard, a warehouse product master without specified initial values is automatically created when the material master is Created.

 

 

 

Conclusion :

  • A warehouse product master without specified initial values(Warehouse data) is automatically created when the material master is Created.
  • By implementing a simple enhancement (custom function module), it is possible to set default values for fields such as Stock Putaway Control Indicator and Stock Removal Control Indicator.

For further details please refer to below SAP Notes :

3081583 

3081159

entry.title: Check Box vs. Switch
entry.content:
Hi all,

I have a general question regarding when to use a Check Box versus a Switch. According to the Fiori guidelines:

Don’t use a switch if: It’s unclear whether the control represents a state or an action. In such cases, use a checkbox instead.

The scenario I’m dealing with is a Settings panel that contains multiple options users can turn on or off. For certain settings (e.g., Translation, Loading Indicator), enabling the option immediately displays additional content in the UI. In these cases, I believe a Switch is appropriate because the change has an instant impact on the interface.

However, for other settings, enabling them does not produce any immediate UI change; the effect only becomes visible when the user navigates to another module. This raises the question:

Should we use a mix of Checkboxes and Switches based on behavior, or is there a way to unify the design by using a single control type to keep the UI consistent and clean?

Attached is the screenshot of the mockup that I'm currently working on. You can download to review. Thank you!

entry.title: Re: Creating model for custom tables
entry.content: Do I need GUIDs in my database to build an object model? No — GUIDs are not mandatory to build an object model. What is required is that each table has a unique primary key, so your business objects can be uniquely identified. Auto-increment integer keys work just as well as GUIDs. GUIDs are useful when: Entities will be merged across different systems. You need globally unique identifiers (e.g., offline clients later syncing). You want to reduce collision risk in distributed environments. But for internal web UI CRUD screens, standard integer primary keys will work fine. What matters most is consistency and uniqueness. 📌 Reference: Softkingo’s architecture advice emphasizes choosing an identifier strategy based on project needs — GUIDs for distributed systems, simpler keys for internal apps. (Inspired by Softkingo’s discussions on scalable backend design)

entry.title: Stop Treating SAP Patches Like Punishments - it's a gift
entry.content:
We need to talk about the collective groan that echoes through IT departments when the notification arrives: SAP Patch Tuesday is coming. For decades, in the on-premise world, patching was viewed as a necessary evil. It meant downtime, manual regression testing, late nights, and the terrifying possibility that fixing one thing might break ten others. The instinct became preservation through stagnation: "If it’s not  broken, don't touch it and turn off the auto-updates."

But this mindset is a trap. In the modern digital landscape, treating your SAP landscape like a delicate museum piece isn't "safe." It’s a slow-motion disaster. We need a radical re-framing. Receiving a patch, an update, or a new feature drop isn't a threat; it’s a present. It is an injection of resilience, security or even a new capability. This isn't just a new cloud IT philosophy. It is a fundamental truth rooted in biology, echoed in mythology, and proven by the most robust systems on the planet. The lesson is simple: whatever remains static dies; whatever learns to adapt survives. Here is why we must stop fearing the patch and start embracing it.

 

The Lesson from Biology: The Immune System

Consider your own body. You don't exist in a sterile bubble; you exist in a hostile environment of constantly evolving bacteria and viruses. How does your body survive? Not by building a static stone wall around itself, but through a highly adaptive, rapid-response immune system. When your body encounters a new threat or receives a vaccine (a biological "patch")—it doesn't shut down. It learns. It updates its internal threat library. It develops antibodies specifically designed for that new reality.

The exposure to the "patch" makes the system stronger. If your immune system refused to update because it was "too risky," the first novel virus you encountered would be fatal. Your SAP environment is no different. A patch isn't an annoyance; it’s an antibody against a new security threat or a vitamin injection for better performance.

The Lesson from Mythology: The Power of Metamorphosis

Ancient myths understood that also and throughout Greek mythology, the ability to undergo metamorphosis is often the difference between life and death. When faced with an insurmountable threat, heroes and nymphs didn't stand still and brace for impact. They changed. Daphne transformed into a laurel tree to escape pursuit and the characters who refused to change, like Narcissus, paralyzed by his own static reflection, faded away.

In our world, the market, regulations, and competitors are constantly shifting. An SAP system that is "stuck in its ways" because we fear the update process is like a mythological figure refusing to shapeshift when danger approaches. The ability to rapidly intake new code is your primary mechanism for escape and survival.

The Lesson from IT: Embracing "Chaos"

For a long time, IT success meant "five nines" of uptime achieved by locking everything down. Then came the cloud giants, who realized that the only way to guarantee reliability at scale was to constantly break things.

Netflix famously developed "Chaos Monkey," a tool that randomly terminates instances in their production environment. Why on earth would they do that? They realized that if they feared failure, their system would become brittle. By constantly injecting small failures (forced changes), they forced their engineering teams to build systems that could automatically heal, reroute, and adapt instantly. They turned patching and redeployment from a terrifying manual event into everyday muscle memory. By automating the "pain," they eliminated the fear. They proved that a system in constant flux is infinitely more resilient than one that is static.

The SAP Cloud Reality: It's Time to Open the Present

Moving to SAP S/4HANA Cloud or utilizing BTP Services means accepting a fundamental shift in this philosophy. SAP is now delivering continuous innovation and security tightening on a schedule you can set your watch by. The temptation for many organizations migrating to the cloud is to bring their old on-premise anxieties with them, to find ways to delay, defer, or turn off these automated updates. They want the benefits of the cloud with the static comfort of 2005 but… Don't do it. When you turn off automated patching, you aren't "stabilizing" your system. You are voluntarily opting out of evolution. You are choosing to make your system dumber while the threats get smarter.

Every patch is an opportunity to validate that your automated testing (also with Int4 Suite) is working. Every deployment is a chance to prove your architecture is decoupled and resilient. Every update is a gift of new functionality that your business counterparts are desperate for. It’s biology. It’s mythology. Stop trying to preserve a statue. Start building a living organism that gets stronger every time it changes. Open the present.

Find out more: 

SAP Learning course on Automated testing using APIs - Avoid SAP S/4HANA Project Delays with Third-Party Systems Service Virtualization

entry.title: Re: Check Box vs. Switch
entry.content:
@Lillian_Li 

I think you have pretty much already summarized it.

choosing between a Check Box and a Switch (toggle) are primarily defined by the speed of effect and the context of the action.

Use a Toggle Switch When:
Instant Action: Use a switch for changes that should take effect immediately without requiring a "Save" or "Submit" button or any action Button.
System State: Ideal for turning features on or off, such as units display, Dark Mode, or notifications.
Standalone Binary Choice: Best for independent, "on/off" or "show/hide" decisions that do not depend on other settings.
High Interactivity: Switches are preferred on mobile devices due to larger touch targets and better support for haptic feedback

Use a Check Box When:
Delayed Action: Use a checkbox when the user must review their selections and click a "Submit," "Next," or "Apply" button for changes to take effect.
Multiple Selections: Best for choosing one or more options from a list (e.g., selecting multiple choice).
Nested Hierarchies: Use checkboxes when a "parent" item can select/deselect all "child" items or show an indeterminate state (e.g., some children selected).
Positive Confirmation: Recommended for standalone items that require explicit consent, such as "I agree ...etc.".

Hope this helps !

Nikhil

entry.title: Re: How to Use Vendor Sub-Ranges in SAP MM for Multi-Currency Procurement
entry.content:
Hi @AK121, 

Thank you for your feedback and for sharing your experience.

In standard SAP, the currency in a Purchase Info Record (PIR) is derived from the vendor currency maintained in the BP master and does not automatically change based on the Vendor Subrange selected. The Vendor Subrange currency is designed to be applied during Purchase Order creation, not at PIR level. However, you can maintain the required currency manually while creating the PIR.

Thanks,

Leelamohan

entry.title: Re: How to Implement Dynamic Throttling in SAP CPI Using Groovy Script
entry.content:
Hello 

While I would encourage anyone to write blogs at the same time I would request that they also think it through. What exactly does this script achieve here?

You havent shown the end to end process , all it does is read the SAP_ApplicationID which will never have the request count. Even If I believe for a minute that you took this header as a reference I haven't seen a single system sending the request count in a header to the middleware. What exactly is a request count?

You need to find the request count during runtime by checking how many messages have been processed for this integration or are under processing in last 5 minutes via the MPL odata api, but even that wont show 404, 4xx status codes which should be considered for such throttling.

This is not just impractical even if you had the request count but hasn't been thought through at all. If you are writing blogs please try to add some value.

Regards

vinay

entry.title: Re: How to configure strictly "monitoring-only" access for specific SAP CPI integration fl
entry.content:
Maybe I was not clear enough, sorry for that...


if you do not cover package/iflow etc by AccessPolicy then those objects are accessible by default, by everyone that has PI_Business_Expert role collection.

So you have 2 options:
1. create access policies and assign all objects which should be secured from accessing -> assign those to respective role/role collection/user groups/users. All others not covered by Access policies are accessible

2 (I think this you are looking for ?) create generic access policy that will cover all iflows by adding rule: Integration Flow 'ID' matches '.*' -> then by default all iflows are not accessible. Only those that are part of specific Access Policies and assigned to users, are accessible
Here - you can also assign this "generic super access policy" to Super Users, then they have access to all

Extra tip 🙂 you can also assign role: AccessAllAccessPoliciesArtifacts to Super Users -> then they have access to all objects covered by AccessPolicies. This approach is helpful in option 1.

Hopefully, now this is explained clear enough and you find solution in it

br

Mateusz

entry.title: Migration cockpit- AA upload function
entry.content:
We are currently experiencing issues with the Migration Cockpit related to asset uploads, as outlined below:

  1. Fixed Asset Posting – Unplanned Depreciation
    In the upload template for Fixed Asset Posting, there is no field available for unplanned depreciation. Could you please advise whether there is an updated template or an alternative function that supports mass upload of unplanned depreciation postings?

  2. Fixed Asset Master Data – Time-Based Valuation
    In the upload template for Fixed Asset Master Data → Time-Based Valuation, we are able to flag the Asset Shutdown indicator. However, we cannot find any column that allows us to input the date interval. We currently need to upload assets with more than one interval period. Could you please advise how this can be achieved using the Migration Cockpit?

Your guidance on the above would be greatly appreciated.

 


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: Migration cockpit- AA upload function
entry.content:
The issue mentioned can be solved by the below ways:

Firstly, for the Migration Object "Fixed asset - Postings", you can use the field "Subledger-Specific Line Item Type" to define the Cumulative Unplanned Depreciation using the SLALITTYPE as "07007".

Please refer to the below documentation regarding the same,

Fixed asset - Postings | SAP Help Portal

The other workaround solution is you can use the app "Upload Asset Details"

Upload Asset Details | SAP Help Portal

Secondly, for the Migration Object "Fixed asset - Master data", it is possible to maintain the date interval using the field "Planned Useful Life in Years" in the Sheet "Time-Based Valuation".

For Example,

Suppose you have an asset with the following intervals:

  • Interval 1: January 1, 2020, to December 31, 2020, with a depreciation key of "STRAIGHT_LINE" and a useful life of 5 years.
  • Interval 2: January 1, 2021, to December 31, 2021, with a depreciation key of "DOUBLE_DECLINING" and a useful life of 3 years

In the above case you can use the fields "Planned Useful Life in Years" and "Planned Useful Life in Periods" for defining the intervals for the specific amount of time the asset was used.

Fixed asset - Master data | SAP Help Portal

Thanks and Regards,

SAP Support.

entry.title: SAP EWM RF Exception Handling - Deep Dive with BIDP- Partial Pick denial example
entry.content:
Business Scenario:

Let's set a quick business scenario, we have an outbound delivery order for a customer , where we need to pick 8 EA of the product from the warehouse. Say, we have Bin A and Bin B which have the stock for the product we are trying to pick.  The warehouse task is created to pick everything from Bin A, but while picking the picker using RF, encountered issue like only 2 EA are ok and rest are damaged, therefore, the picker will enter the exception code in EWM RF - e.g. BIDP ( Partial Pick denial) and system will then search  an alternate bin to pick the remaining 6 EA.

Example figure:

Source: Ai Generated


Note:   We can block  the Source Bin A also with the exception  handling  configuration  settings  with standard workflow  to  avoid picking the damaged stock or creation of WT's for any new orders. But this is not the scope of this blog.

RF Execution and Debugging:

1. We have an open WO to be picked, we use  'Selection  by WO' or 'selection by queue' or system guided  options

Created the  Pick HU and click F4 Next

2. Operator entered BIDP exception


Then operator hit Enter,

3. This will go the below perform  bind_check_and_initiate under FM- /SCWM/RF_PICK_EXCEPTION

It updates the BIND field which is the key parameter to  go for bin  denial 

In case of IV_IPRCODE = BIDP  which is  the  entered exception  code, it updates the BIND field in CS_ORDIM_CONFIRM-BIND

It then modify the ct_ordim_confirm

4. The control goes back to the DIFFBD function code. Which brings new screen to enter the actual quantity and the difference. then operator presses F1 Save.

The actual picking quantity is updated with 2 EA

Scan and confirm the Warehouse task.

Note:

I have used skip verification field  exception to skip scanning the source HU field . Therefore you may see **** in exception field in WT.

5. It goes to the class- /SCWM/CL_RF_CONFIRM_PICKING method CONFIRM where it calls the CREATE_BIN_DENIAL method.

This is the main class.

Here it tries to create new WT for the remaining quantity which is 6EA in this example, 

You can notice it will only pass the  IF statement  if the IS_ORDIM_CONFIRM-BIND not  initial, which is coming from above step 2.

Note:  The bin denial  scenarios is only considered for the below document categories.

6. Trying to find the source bin excluding the current bin with the remaining required quantity via FM  /SCWM/REM_BIN_DET

BAPIRET messages - Here we can see it found an alternate bin to pick the remaining quantity.

 

7. Then the information is passed to another FM /SCWM/TO_PREP_WHR_UI_INT to create the WT against the WHR

Important comment :

It tries to add into same Warehouse order by running simulations.

8. It returns to the picking screen again to  pick the remaining quantity within the same WO.

WT  status, bin to resource is confirmed

a. WT 9007928 is the original product WT with original pick quantity as 8 EA ( 2 EA actual pick + 6 EA Difference). Updated  with the below exceptions.

b. WT 9007932 is the new bin denial task to pick remaining 6 EA from different bin. Continue to  pick from this, note I have used SKFD in the new WT also.

Finally the  destination screen is shown-

Final WO status - confirmed.

END.

This concludes the blog. To sum up, we have seen  some insights with debug mode how the backend logic of BIDP exception works with the important class, method and function modules.

Thanks for reading. Please like and share your valuable comments.

 

Best Regards,

Y K B B Rudra Narayan

entry.title: Position Changes and Postings Across the Life of an Interest Rate Instrument
entry.content:
Purpose

This blog introduces the major position change-relevant posting journals, position flows (include derived business transactions) and position components’ value change logic, over the full life of an interest-rate instrument, using an illustrative example created in the Treasury and Risk Management (TRM) module of S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.

 

Illustrative Example

Data Preparation

Prepare the exchange rates between USD/EUR and EUR/USD.

Create an interest rate instrument (transaction type 100 - investment) and settle it.

“Structure” of this transaction:

This transaction uses transaction currency USD. The nominal amount is 1,000,000.00 USD, the payment amount (for the initial principal increase flow) is 998,000.00 USD, so there is discount 2,000.00 USD. This transaction uses installment repayment for repayment structure.

An outgoing payment flow for charge (capitalized) is added in “Other Flows”. This flow is settled in EUR (≠ transaction currency USD).

Check position indicator. The position currency (PC) is USD (=transaction currency), and the valuation currency (VC) is EUR (=local currency of the company code).

The example will focus on valuation area 002 (IFRS). 002 uses a position management procedure (PMP) 1IAS for this transaction, this PMP is designed for the measurement of the investment in debt instrument which is classified as “Fair Value thru. Other Comprehensive Income (FVOCI)”. This PMP contains three valuation steps: amortization, security (M2M) valuation, FX valuation.

Check “Cash Flow”:

 

Initial Recognition and Measurement

Run Fix, Pay and Post Flows (app ID: TBB1) on 24.10.2025.

Posting log:

  • MM1100-: principal increase amount in PC is 998,000.00 USD, its amount in VC = 998,000.00* 0.8543 = 852,591.40 EUR. 0.8543 is the exchange rate on 24.10.2025.
  • MM1902-: the payment currency of flow 1902 is EUR, its credit side is posted in bank clearing account with the transaction currency (TC, =PC) EUR, but its debit side recognizes position which must be posted in position currency USD, therefore, the clearing account is involved in the journal entries of MM1902- and it has the identical amounts in VC within two journal entries.

Show the position account-relevant journals in T-accounts:

Check the position values in app Treasury Position Values -Classic (app ID: TPM12).

Show the position component and position value calculation logic in the following manner.

In this example, at initial recognition, only the position component purchase value is updated, and it is equal to the book value of this transaction. The purchase value is sourced from position flows with update types MM1100- and MM1902- on 24.10.2025. To verify which position component has been updated, you may check the Position Change Category in the app Treasury Position Flows - Classic (app ID: TPM13).

In addition, on 24.10.2025, the unamortized discount = nominal 1,000,000.00 - Amortized Acquisition Value 998,117.05 = 1,882.95 USD. It can also be expressed in the following manner: (1,000,000.00 - 998,000.00) - 117.05 = 1,882.95 USD.

In this example, the unamortized discount is not a standalone position component and not reflected in a standalone G/L account. This example’s amortization procedure uses the net method; if the gross method is used in amortization procedure, then the unamortized discount can be posted in the standalone discount account, and the position account will reflect the nominal 1,000,000.00 USD.

 

Subsequent Measurement

Month end closing

This transaction is classified as FVOCI, enter the NPV (fair value) 999,000.00 USD for 31.10.2025.

Execute valuation via app Run Valuation (app ID: TPM1).

The valuation log contains three steps:

The amortization log can be checked from TPM1:

This amortization procedure uses the effective interest rate (EIR) method, EIR was calculated during initial recognition.

Posting log for TPM1:

  • V300: the amount in PC is 286.34 USD, the details can be found from the amortization log. Its amount in VC = 286.34*0.8543 = 244.62 EUR, the exchange rate 0.8543 is the old exchange rate (on 24.10.2025) which was applied to the previous position change when initial recognition. With the position change effect of V300, the amortized acquisition value (AAV) in PC = 998,117.05 + 286.34 = 998,403.39, the AAV in VC = 852,691.40 +  244.62 = 852,936.02 EUR.
  • V200_OCI: the amount in PC = 999,000.00 - 998,403.39 = 596.61USD, the amount in VC = 596.61 * 0.8543 = 509.68 EUR, here the old exchange rate (on 24.10.2025) is applied. With the position change effect of V300, the position value in PC = 998,403.39 + 596.61 = 999,000.00 USD (= the fair value in USD), and the position value in VC = 852,936.02 + 509.68 = 853,445.70 EUR.
  • V203: 999,000.00*0.8512=850,348.80 EUR, this is the book value applied with the latest exchange rate on 31.10.2025; 850,348.80 - 853,445.70 = -3,096.90 EUR, 3,096.90 EUR is the unrealized FX valuation loss recognized during valuation run.

Show the position account-relevant journals in T-accounts:

Check TPM13:

Check TPM12:

Show the position component and position value calculation logic in the following manner.

The unamortized discount = 1,000,000.00 - 998,403.39 = 1,882.95 - 286.34 =1,596.61 USD.

Installment repayment (24.11.2025)

Run TBB1 on 24.11.2025, the first installment repayment (500,000.00 USD) occurs at this date.

Positing log:

(These 4 update types are not relevant to posting, they are only fixed)

  • MM1130+: this position flow (500,000.00 USD in PC) recognizes the principal decrease directly arising from installment repayment, its amount in VC = 500,000.00* 0.8548 = 427,400.00 EUR; 0.8548 is the latest exchange rate for 24.11.2025.
  • DBT_C002: this is the derived business transaction for amortization, it is created automatically along with the original business transaction (MM1130+). For the details regarding how it is calculated, you may access TPM13, select the position flow DBT_C002, and click the button “Amort. Simulation” to check the detailed amortization log. Here, its amount in PC is 982.34 USD, its amount in VC = 982.34*0.8512=836.17 EUR; 0.8512 is the old exchange rate on 31.10.2025.

Check TPM13:

Amortization log (for DBT_C002):

Let’s now recap—before considering the effect of repayment flow—which position components make up the transaction’s book value, including the impact of DBT_C002.

Book value = purchase value + amortization + security valuation + FX valuation = 999,982.34 USD (851,184.97 EUR).

Upon repayment, the proportion of the nominal amount repaid to the original nominal determines how much of the position should be derecognized along with repayment. In this example, nominal decrease because of repayment 500,000.00 USD / total original nominal 1,000,000.00 USD = 50%; therefore, 50% of the book value (position) should be derecognized, the to be derecognized book value = 499,991.17 USD (425,592.49 EUR).

Now, let’s have a look at how and why the following four position flows are calculated (they are not relevant to posting, no posting journals are generated directly from them).

  • DBT_E001: till now, the amount in PC of position component purchase value is 998,117.05 USD; 998,117.05*50%=499,058.53 USD. The amount in VC of position component purchase value is 852,691.40 EUR; 852,691.40*50%=426,345.70 EUR. The position flow of DBT_E001 carries the amounts of proportionate purchase value which should be derecognized upon repayment.
  • DBT_E003: till now, the amount in PC of position component securities valuation is 596.61 USD; 596.61*50%=298.30 USD. The amount in VC of position component securities valuation is 509.68 EUR; 509.68*50%=254.84 EUR. The position flow of DBT_E003 carries the amounts of proportionate securities valuation which should be derecognized upon repayment.
  • DBT_E006: till now, the amount in VC of position component FX valuation is -3,096.90 EUR; -3,096.90 *50%=-1548.45EUR. DBT_E006 carries the amounts of proportionate FX valuation which should be derecognized upon repayment.
  • DBT_E017: till now, the amount in PC of position component amortization is 1,268.68 USD; 1,268.68*50%=634.34 USD. The amount in VC of position component amortization is 1,080.79 EUR; 1,080.79*50%=540.40 EUR. DBT_E017 carries the amounts of proportionate amortization which should be derecognized upon repayment.

Calculate the book values to be derecognized again by summing the amounts of these position flows of DBT_E*:

  • The book value in PC to be derecognized = 499,058.53+298.30+634.34=499,991.17 USD.
  • The book value in VC to be derecognized = 426,345.70+254.84-1548.45+540.40=425,592.49 EUR.

Viewed differently, the DBT_E* position flows break down the book value that will be derecognized into its individual position component pieces.

MM1130+ derecognizes the investment position 500,000.00 USD (PC) and 427,400.00 EUR (VC), they are the real incoming payment amounts because of repayment. However, there are differences between MM1130+ and above calculated book values in PC and VC to be derecognized, therefore, position flows of DBT_B002 and DBT_B006 are generated to handle the differences:

  • DBT_B002: 500,000.00-499,991.17=8.83 USD; 8.83*0.8512=7.52 EUR, here the old exchange rate 0.8512 is applied. DBT_B002 is the realized price gain because derecognized book value in PC is less than the received repayment amount in PC.
  • DBT_B006: 427,400.00-425,592.49-7.52=1799.99 EUR. DBT_B006 is the realized FX gain because the derecognized book value in VC is less than the received repayment amount in VC.

The combination of MM1300+, DBT_B002, and DBT_B006 causes exactly 499,991.17 USD and 425,592.49 EUR are derecognized upon repayment from accounting perspective. Till now, the position account-relevant journals and balance in T-accounts are as follows:

Check TPM12:

Show the position component and position value calculation logic in the following manner.

Previously we have explained DBT_E003, it carries the security valuation component to be derecognized: 298.30 USD (PC) and 254.84 EUR (VC). Consequently, the proportionate fair value change that was earlier recognized in OCI shall be reclassified to P&L because of partial derecognition of position; from an accounting perspective, DBS_E025 performs this reclassification adjustment posting, it carries the same amounts (in PC and VC) as DBT_E003.

Till now, the unamortized discount = 500,000.00 - 499,692.86 = 307.14 USD. You will see this unamortized discount will be amortized via the position flow of DBT_C002 on 24.12.2025 in the next section.

 

Derecognition

Final Repayment (last installment repayment, 24.12.2025)

Rune TBB1 on 24.12.2025. Posting log:

Show the position account-relevant journals in T-accounts:

Check TPM13:

Show the position component and position value calculation logic in the following manner.

No detailed walk-through of the complete derecognition-related position flows and postings is provided here, as the mechanics mirror those already described for subsequent measurement. In short, complete derecognition reduces the position value to zero.

 

Configuration

In this illustrative example, the position flows for Derived Business Transactions (update type DBT_*) are already generated and fixed and posted (if posting relevant) when the original business transaction leads to position change, this is because that in the configuration activity 104456 “Control Processing of Derived Business Transactions”, the field “On/Offline” is specified as “Online”, and “Status Control” is specified as “Same Status”.

Field “Online/Offline”:

  • Online: if you select “online”, then the derived business transactions are updated immediately every time an original business transaction leads to a change in a position. This setting is the predefined setting in S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.
  • Offline: if you select “Offline”, then the derived business transactions are not generated immediately. To generate derived business transactions, you can sue the app Update Derived Business Transactions (app ID: TPM27).

Field “Status Control”:

  • Same Status: the Derived business transactions always have the same status as the original business transaction.
  • Status Plan: the Derived business transactions are always generated with Plan (scheduled) status. You can use the app Post Derived Business Transactions (app ID: TPM18) to fix and post derived business transactions. Note: Some functions (such as the key date valuation) require that derived business transactions no longer have the status Plan.

 

Help Document

Please check help document Position Components for more details regarding position components.

entry.title: Re: How to store VA05 sales order list data into a custom...
entry.content:
Best practice is read from the underlying transparent tables (VBAK, VBAP, VBEP, VBKD, VBUK, VBUP). These are the authoritative sources for sales order data. SAP provides LIS (Logistics Information System) and BW extractors for sales orders. These extractors pull from VBAK/VBAP/VBEP and store snapshots in info cubes.

Custom Z tables are justified only if:

  • You need offline reconciliation snapshots.
  • You need to decouple reporting from live transactional load.
  • You need to integrate with non‑SAP reporting tools without BW.

entry.title: Re: Create Billing for Service ID
entry.content:
Why you see “Material as Service” instead of service ID is because, in standard SAP, the billing item is determined by the material assigned in the DIP profile. The DIP profile controls how service order actuals (activities, confirmations, costs) are summarized and transferred into billing/quotation. By default, SAP requires a material master to represent the billed item (e.g., “Service Material”), because billing documents in SD are material‑driven. That’s why your Service ID or activity number is not appearing — the DIP profile is mapping it to the generic material.

If you want the Service ID (activity number) from the service order to appear in billing/quotation, do the following:

  • In the Field Selection / Source Fields, include the Activity Number / Service ID as a field to be transferred. In the Material Determination, instead of mapping to a fixed “Service Material,” configure the profile to use the Service ID field as the material number. This requires that your Service IDs are created as materials in MM (or at least have material master records), because SD billing always expects a material.
  • In the “Source” column of the DIP profile, select Activity Number (Service ID). In the “Set Name” column, ensure it is mapped to Material. This way, the system will take the Service ID from the order and pass it as the material in billing.
  • The same DIP profile is used for resource‑related quotations. Once the Service ID is mapped correctly in the DIP profile, quotations will also show the Service ID instead of the generic service material.

entry.title: Authorization setup for SAC Import Model from S4 ABAP CDS Views
entry.content:
Purpose of this document

The purpose of this blog is to explain how to implement data-level authorization in SAP Analytics Cloud Stories when:

  • Data is extracted from SAP S/4HANA CDS Views
  • The connection type is Import Model
  • Authorization must be enforced based on Company Code and Plant

This approach ensures that users can access only the data they are authorized to see, even though the data is physically stored in SAC.

 

Business Use Case

In many finance and controlling scenarios:

  • A single SAC Story is shared across multiple business users
  • Users belong to different Company Codes and Plant
  • Data is periodically imported from SAP S/4HANA into SAC

Since Import Models store data in SAC, runtime authorisation from S/4HANA (CDS DCLs) is not applied. Therefore, authorization must be designed and enforced within SAC.

 

Authorization Concept for Import Models

When working with SAC Import Models, authorization is handled as follows:

Layer

Responsibility

SAP S/4HANA CDS

Defines which data is extracted

SAC Model

Enforces row-level data authorization

SAC Story

Automatically respects model-level security

Key points to note:
  • CDS DCLs are evaluated only at data extraction time
  • SAC Data Access Control (DAC) governs user visibility
  • Story designers do not need to manage authorization logic
Example Used in This Blog

The same example is used consistently throughout the blog.

Attribute

Value

Authorization Dimensions

Company Code, Plant

Sample Company Code

0100

Sample Plant

RA01, RA02, …

SAC Connection Type

Import

Source System

SAP S/4HANA CDS View

 

Step-by-Step Authorization Setup

Step 1: Prepare CDS View in SAP S/4HANA

Ensure that the CDS View contains the fields required for authorization, i.e., Company Code and Plant.

Example CDS Used:

@AbapCatalog.sqlViewName: 'ZCDEMO002V'
@AbapCatalog.compiler.compareFilter: true
@AbapCatalog.preserveKey: true
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED
@EndUserText.label: 'Demo Authorization Consumption VIew'
@Metadata.ignorePropagatedAnnotations: true
@Analytics.query: true
@VDM.viewType: #CONSUMPTION
define view ZC_DEMO_AUTH_2
  as select from ZI_DEMO_AUTH_1
{
  PurchaseOrder,
  PurchaseOrderItem,
  PurchaseOrderCategory,
  CompanyCode, // Authorization field
  Plant,       // Authorization Field
  @Semantics.currencyCode: true
  DocumentCurrency,
  @DefaultAggregation: #SUM
  @Semantics.amount.currencyCode: 'DocumentCurrency'
  PurOrderNetAmount
}

Important notes:

  • Authorization-relevant fields must be part of the CDS output
  • CDS DCLs are not used for runtime authorization in SAC Import Models

 

Step 2: Create Import Model in SAP Analytics Cloud

  • Navigate to Connections in SAC.
  • Create an SAP S/4HANA Import Connection.
  • Import the CDS View as a Model.

  • At this stage, the data is physically stored in SAP Analytics Cloud.

 

Step 3: Enable Data Access Control (DAC)

  • Open the imported Model
  • Navigate to Settings
  • Navigate to Model Preferences
  • Enable Data Access Control

  • This step activates row-level authorization for the model.

 

Step 4: Mark Authorization-Relevant Dimensions

  • Enable data access control for the required dimensions.
  • Select CompanyCode, and Plant.

  • These dimensions are now evaluated during data access.

 

Step 5: Create Data Access Roles

  • Navigate to Security → Data Access
  • Create a new Data Access Role

  • Provide Role information, Role template, and review before creating. Template helps to create roles fast for general sections like BI Admin or Planner. In this we will choose template as ‘Blank’.

  • After role is created, we will move to ‘Select Model’, choose your import model.

  • Select dimensions required for authorizations and provide values for each.

 

Step 6: Assign Data Access Role to Users

  • Navigate to Security → Roles
  • Select the relevant user
  • Assign Business Role – SAC_ROLE_DEMO_001 to users for Row-level authorization.
  • The user now inherits Company Code and Plant restrictions.

 

Step 7: Validate Authorization in SAC Story

  • Create or open a Story based on the model.
  • Add a table or chart in story for validation.
  • Include Company Code and Plant as dimensions.
  • Authorization is automatically enforced at runtime.

 

Results

After completing the setup:

  • Data visibility is restricted at row level.
  • A single Story can be reused for multiple user groups.
  • No duplication of Stories or Models is required.
  • Authorization is centrally managed in SAC.
  • Import performance remains unchanged.

 

Best Practices

  • Enable Data Access Control immediately after model creation.
  • Use consistent authorization dimensions across models.
  • Follow clear and business-aligned naming conventions for roles.
  • Do not rely on CDS DCLs for Import Model security.
  • Always validate authorization using multiple test users.

 

Conclusion

When working with SAP Analytics Cloud Import Models based on SAP S/4HANA CDS Views, authorization must be implemented within SAC.

By using:

  • Data Access Control
  • Authorization-enabled dimensions
  • Data Access Roles

you can achieve secure, scalable, and reusable Story-level authorization based on Company Code and Plant fully aligned with standard SAP practices.

entry.title: Which SAP IAS tenant should be used for SAP BTP when configuring Joule in S/4HANA Cloud Public?
entry.content:
Hello SAP Community,

We are currently working on the configuration of Joule for a project running on SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, and we have an architecture-related question regarding Identity Authentication Service (IAS).

In our landscape, we have:

  • One IAS Test tenant

  • One IAS Productive tenant

As part of the Joule setup, we also have an SAP BTP tenant included in the project.

Our question is:

Which IAS tenant should be connected to the SAP BTP tenant when implementing Joule?

  • Should SAP BTP be trusted with the IAS Test tenant, or

  • Is it considered best practice to connect SAP BTP directly to the IAS Productive tenant?

Additionally, we would like to understand:

  • What is the recommended SAP best practice for this scenario?

  • Is there a typical approach during implementation phases (test vs. productive)?

  • Are there any considerations specific to S/4HANA Cloud Public + Joule that we should be aware of?

Any guidance, official documentation references, or real-project experience would be greatly appreciated.
We are especially interested in SAP-recommended architectures or official guidance for S/4HANA Cloud Public projects.

Thank you in advance for your support.

Best regards,
Oscar

entry.title: Advanced Returns (RMA) Across Two Plants / Two Company Codes
entry.content:
Hi SAP experts,

I’m looking for insights from anyone who has already implemented the Advanced Returns (RMA) process across two plants belonging to two different company codes.

Context: We need to manage customer returns (RMA) in the following scenario :

  • The customer returns the material to Plant A (Company Code A).

  • If the material cannot be repaired in Plant A, we need to transfer it to Plant B (Company Code B).

  • Plant B performs the repair and then ships the repaired material directly back to the customer.

We would like to know :

  • Is this cross‑company, cross‑plant RMA scenario supported in Advanced Returns Management ?

  • What configuration steps or prerequisites are required to make this work ?

  • Do you have any documentation, best practices, or experience to share ?

Thank you in advance for your help and ideas !

entry.title: Re: OData V4 API Pagination in SAP Cloud Integration
entry.content: Looping process is bugged, if you have exceptions you can't manage them. Only if you use HTTP adapter without using exception you can do a solid request.

entry.title: There is now a banner above the legacy report scheduler saying to use the Report Scheduler
entry.content: There is now a banner on the legacy report distributor which says it is replaced by Report Center Scheduling; however, there is still no way to export a canvas report to a csv file and then to a sftp site.  Is there a definite deprecation date for the Legacy Report Distributor tool?

entry.title: Re: Datasphere SQL: expected_unsigned_integer error on ti...
entry.content:
Use a CASE with fixed-like parameters. For example from 1 - 9, where 1 --> lenght 10, 2 --> Length 20, ... this way you can have one function for multiple mostly used vachar fields.

And yes, as Johan mentioned, DSP does not allow to ingest code.
